questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you should:
questions.answerB: Know the tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: Start driving and see if the vehicle is handling well.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system is extremely hazardous because it can permit poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer ____ of the violation.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.answerD: Putting your hand out the driver's side window and waving.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: If an Anti-Locking Braking System (ABS) is not working on a truck:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at low speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Back up after the students board the bus.
questions.answerC: Back up while students direct you.
questions.explanation: Backing in a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other safe way to move the vehicle. If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should wait until all students have first loaded the bus.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: When a school bus is approaching a bus stop, the driver should:
questions.explanation: School bus drivers should approach stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and there is no nearby shelter, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough away from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: While students load and unload a bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch the process and keep an eye on the students.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: What should properly adjusted outside side flat mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see?
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, the outside side flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see along the sides of the bus; the rear tires touching the ground; and 200 feet behind the bus.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: About how many seconds in advance of a bus stop should warning lights be activated?
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating amber warning lights, they must be activated at least 200 feet, or about five to ten seconds, before the stop.

questions.question: When boarding a school bus, students should:
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly and in a single-file line. For safety, boarding students should use the handrail.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: If students on the bus cause a disturbance while other students are unloading, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Immediately walk to the back of the bus and take care of the disturbance while students unload.
questions.answerB: Wait until the students are done unloading and then take care of the disturbance.
questions.answerC: Have a student who is closer to the disturbance handle the situation while you supervise unloading.
questions.explanation: The process of loading or unloading students from a school bus requires a driver's full concentration. If there is a behavioral issue on the bus, wait until the exiting students are safely off the bus and out of the way before you address the problem on the bus.

questions.question: What do outside crossover mirrors allow a driver to see?
questions.answerC: The right side of the bus
questions.answerD: The left side of the bus
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a school bus driver see the danger zone area directly in front of the bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts.
questions.answerC: The rear door of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus, the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts, and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if students are given notice of the change.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students and parents.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the school and not changed.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should never change or add a stop without written approval from the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: When entering traffic on an expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerC: Abruptly enter a lane of traffic.
questions.answerD: Cut off other drivers if needed.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to enter an expressway. Before doing so, you must check traffic, use proper signals, and merge smoothly into the proper lane.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: Adjust a bus's mirrors:
questions.answerC: At the first stoplight after starting your shift.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of mirrors should be checked prior to the start of any trip.

questions.question: If your bus is equipped with a roof-mounted strobe light, it should be used:
questions.explanation: If equipped, a school bus's roof-mounted strobe light should be used when conditions create an environment of limited visibility.

questions.question: What should properly adjusted outside side flat mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see?
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, the outside side flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see along the sides of the bus; the rear tires touching the ground; and 200 feet behind the bus.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a security check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: What can be a clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The shipper is a business you might expect to deal with hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The road is made of gravel.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical suppliers, scientific supply houses, pest control companies, agricultural suppliers, and dealers in explosives, fireworks, or munitions.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo catches on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put out the fire with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Continue driving to the fire department.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires specialized training and equipment. Unless you possess these yourself, it is best to let emergency personnel deal with the fire.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must have an approved gas mask in the vehicle, as well as an emergency kit for controlling leaks in dome cover plate fittings on the cargo tank.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: A placard should be placed:
questions.answerA: At least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: Under a ladder, if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: On a background that is a similar color to the placard.
questions.explanation: A placard must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings. The placard should be kept clear of attachments or devices, such as doors and ladders. Placards should always be placed against a background of a contrasting color.

questions.question: Shipping papers identifying hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerA: At the bottom of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerB: On the top of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerC: In a location separate from non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Carriers and drivers must be able to quickly identify hazardous materials' shipping papers. Shipping papers for hazardous materials should be on the top of a stack of shipping papers.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Due to the risks involved, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials. These regulations exist to protect the driver, others near the vehicle, and the environment.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, what is an effective way to learn about transporting hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening the trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Put on a pair of gloves.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Get someone else to drive it.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for correctly labeling and marking them. The driver should make sure that the shipper properly labeled and marked the materials before beginning a trip.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerA: Does not have to be able to move the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know about the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must stay within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading and unloading of a tank must be watched by a qualified person. They must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the materials involved; know the procedures to follow in an emergency; and be authorized and able to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.explanation: When loading or unloading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use hooks, or any other tools that could damage containers or packaging.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: If accepting a shipment, what could indicate that the cargo contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged on wood pallets.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: What is Gross Combination Weight?
questions.answerA: The total weight of the powered unit, trailer, and cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a single vehicle without its load
questions.answerC: The maximum weight allowed by the manufacturer
questions.explanation: Gross Combination Weight (GCW) is the total weight of a powered unit, its trailer(s), and the cargo being carried.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially:
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out of adjustment if they are hot. Be sure to routinely check the adjustment of your brakes. For a vehicle to be safely controlled, all brakes must be properly functioning and adjusted.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Some water and compressor oil is usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. The water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the system.
questions.answerB: Should take up about 10 percent of the tank.
questions.explanation: If water and compressor oil are left to build up in an air brake system, the system can be damaged. Air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow this accumulation to be removed. Manually controlled drains should be operated at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.explanation: Rollovers occur when drivers turn or change lanes too quickly.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerA: Only occurs at extremely high speeds.
questions.answerB: Can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.
questions.answerC: Happens most frequently when tire pressure is too high.
questions.explanation: If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph. It is most likely if the tires' air pressure is too low or if tires' tread is worn.

questions.question: When should mirror adjustments be made?
questions.answerC: When a vehicle is stopped at a traffic signal
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of each trip. Any attached trailer should be straight while mirrors are being adjusted.

questions.question: What is a way to warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down?
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate the brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get other drivers’ attention.
questions.answerD: Turn all lights on and off several times.
questions.explanation: To alert drivers behind you that you plan to slow down, tap your brake pedal lightly a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: If planning to change lanes, your mirrors should:
questions.answerC: Be checked more often than usual.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal scanning routine, be especially sure to check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: Once cargo is secured:
questions.answerA: You may complete an entire trip without checking it.
questions.answerB: You can drive at least eight hours without checking it.
questions.answerC: You should check it every three hours or 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day because hazards become more difficult to see in the dark.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal. If the warning signal goes off while a vehicle is being driven, the driver should bring the vehicle to a complete stop and have the system repaired.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.explanation: The adjustment of your mirrors should be checked prior to the start of all trips. Adjust your mirrors as needed.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, it is best for the driver to:
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel in one direction, then in the other.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to regain traction. The trailer will begin to straighten out once the wheels begin to grip the road again.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: When entering traffic, the driver of a double or triple needs to be aware that doubles and triples:
questions.answerA: Need more space to merge into traffic than smaller vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are exempt from most speed limits.
questions.answerC: Are difficult for other drivers to see.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples need more space than other vehicles, both because they are longer and because their size and weight prevent them from turning or stopping suddenly. When driving a double or triple, always make sure you have enough space before entering traffic, crossing traffic, or changing lanes.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower will not speed up the process. The only way to become sober is to allow your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: When making a lane change, your turn signal:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if there is traffic present.
questions.answerC: Should only be used between dusk and dawn.
questions.explanation: You must always properly signal before turning or changing lanes.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Federal and state laws require:
questions.answerA: Drivers to regularly inspect their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they believe there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Drivers to inspect their vehicles if planning to travel out-of-state.
questions.answerD: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they will be transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers are required by federal and state laws to inspect their vehicles before every trip. Regular inspections can help drivers identify issues before they become dangerous and costly.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.explanation: The brakes in an air brake system use compressed air to function properly.

questions.question: Routine vehicle inspections should be done to ensure:
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle is to ensure the safety of yourself and other road users.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, your vehicle's braking distance will become ____ times longer.
questions.explanation: If you double your speed, your braking distance will become four times longer. Similarly, the impact your vehicle would have in the case of a collision will also multiply by four.

questions.question: Using the brakes creates heat. If too much heat is produced:
questions.answerB: The brakes may squeak more than usual.
questions.explanation: Brakes are designed to take a lot of heat, but drivers should not rely solely on the brakes to slow their vehicle. Brakes may fade and lose their ability to slow down the vehicle if they become too hot, so drivers should also rely on the engine braking effect.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: If you have an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: To keep an engine fire from spreading, you should turn off the vehicle's engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you don't have to.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: The heavier the vehicle:
questions.answerA: The less important the brakes become.
questions.answerB: The harder the brakes need to work.
questions.answerC: The quieter the brakes will sound.
questions.explanation: The heavier a vehicle is, the more the brakes will need to work to bring the vehicle to a complete stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.answerC: Held with one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, placed on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system, be alert to a number of potential problems, including loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to change gears?
questions.answerC: The speed of the vehicle next to you
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: When starting an engine as part of a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the engine in first gear.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for emergency lines?
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: If you identify a large box in your lane on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerC: Not be worried because another vehicle will likely hit it before your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Swerve into another lane of traffic.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be very careful if you see foreign objects in your lane. Remember that even something that seems relatively light and harmless, like a cardboard box, could contain harder or heavier items that could cause damage to your vehicle.

questions.question: What can the “crack-the-whip” effect do?
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect can cause a trailer to turn over during a lane change. To avoid this phenomenon, drivers should make lane changes at slow, safe speeds.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your cell phone for texting instead of calling.
questions.answerD: Turn up the ringer on your cell phone.
questions.explanation: Areas with heavy traffic, road construction, large numbers of pedestrians, or severe weather demand extra attention from a driver. The driver should avoid all possible distractions while in such areas, including cell phone use.

questions.question: Your engine runs a pump used during the delivery of compressed gas. After delivery, you should turn off the engine ____ unhooking the hoses.
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerA: Exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerB: Exhaust system parts that are leaking
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts made of aluminum
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brake drums or shoes?
questions.answerD: Shoes that are not covered in brake fluid
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Outage:
questions.answerA: Is only a concern in warm weather.
questions.answerB: Is the same for each liquid.
questions.answerC: Should be a factor when determining how much liquid to load into a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: Because liquids expand when their temperatures increase, some space must be left in a tank to accommodate the expansion. This space is referred to as "outage." The amount of required outage is different for different liquids.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: Creating a text is not permitted, but reading a text is.
questions.answerB: Creating a text is permitted, but reading a text is not.
questions.answerC: Neither creating nor reading a text is permitted.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a CMV is prohibited. "Texting" is defined as manually entering text into, or reading text from, an electronic device.

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: To help control liquid surge, a driver should:
questions.answerD: Brake well in advance of a stop.
questions.explanation: Drive vehicles with unbaffled tanks slowly and carefully, especially when stopping and starting. Brake well in advance of any stops and increase your following distance.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
