questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should only be done in poor weather.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used to prevent cargo from sliding while in transit.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Slowly build up pressure over a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to a normal level within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease quickly while the engine runs.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: Roads are the most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with the oil and grease on the road that have not yet washed away.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed into the middle of the lane.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge with a green light:
questions.answerC: You must wait for the light to change to yellow.
questions.explanation: A bus does not need to stop before crossing a drawbridge controlled by a green signal light. The driver should still slow down and verify that it is safe before crossing.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: Once cargo is secured onto a vehicle:
questions.answerA: You do not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: You should not let others inspect the cargo.
questions.answerC: You should check the cargo every 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: Sometimes, when checking the automatic transmission fluid level:
questions.answerA: Your vehicle should be parked uphill.
questions.answerB: Your vehicle should be parked downhill.
questions.answerD: Your vehicle may have to be left running.
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, you may have to leave the engine running to check the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: Carry-on baggage:
questions.answerA: May be left in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Must be stored away from the aisle.
questions.answerC: Must be kept on the rider’s lap.
questions.answerD: Should be placed in the aisle.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should never be allowed to leave baggage in the aisle or doorway of a bus. All luggage and cargo must be positioned in a manner that ensures riders are able to exit by any window or door in an emergency.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase. When approaching a downgrade, choose to travel at a speed that will be safe for the size and weight of your vehicle.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Should be expected to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Could contain a heavy object that could damage vehicles.
questions.explanation: Almost any foreign object on the road poses some potential danger. For example, even something as seemingly harmless as a cardboard box could contain a hard or heavy object that could damage your vehicle.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: When driving on a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Increase the space in front of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: When checking power steering hoses during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Extra hose pieces available for repairs.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection on a vehicle with power steering, be sure to check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: How can you check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times, then hold down the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake squeaks, there may be a problem.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: Bent lock rings:
questions.answerB: Are not a concern in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are dangerous and should not be used.

questions.question: When driving on a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: A bus driver does not need to stop when approaching:
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerA: Allowed if you are contacting your employer.
questions.answerB: Allowed when driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is dangerous and is never permitted while operating a CMV.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: To ensure you do not interfere with traffic while driving a heavy vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass other vehicles while driving uphill.
questions.answerD: Ride the brakes while driving downhill.
questions.explanation: If the weight of your vehicle prevents you from matching the speed of surrounding traffic, you should stay in the right lane, if possible.

questions.question: After picking up passengers at a stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Allow the passengers time to sit or brace themselves before beginning to drive.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn and re-enter traffic.
questions.answerC: Begin driving as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: You should start and stop as smoothly as possible to help prevent passenger injury. After passengers have boarded your bus at a stop, you should allow them time to be seated or to brace themselves before you begin driving.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: Suspension system defects may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Defects to check for when inspecting your vehicle's suspension system include cracked or broken spring hangers; missing or broken leaves in a leaf spring; and leaking shock absorbers. If you spot any of these issues, be sure to have them repaired.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should only be done in poor weather.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used to prevent cargo from sliding while in transit.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: Be sure to thoroughly inspect your tires before a trip. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut, cracked, or otherwise damaged in any way.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, the engine oil pressure should come up to normal:
questions.explanation: After a vehicle's engine is started, the engine's oil pressure should rise to its normal level within seconds. Do not drive a vehicle with oil pressure that is too low.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they can become too hot. This overheating causes them to fade, making them less effective at slowing the vehicle.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most driving situations.
questions.answerC: Can help you maintain control when braking.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air brakes and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle by preventing wheel lockup.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: If using spring brakes when hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes do not work on all axles. If your vehicle's spring brakes activate due to low pressure in an air brake system, your vehicle will need a longer distance to stop than usual, especially if you are carrying a heavy load.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.answerD: Clean the air in the passenger compartment.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes. Manually operated drains should be used daily.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: If using the spring brakes while hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes will activate in a vehicle with air brakes if the pressure in the air system becomes too low. A heavily loaded vehicle will take a long time to stop when using only the spring brakes because the spring brakes do not work on all axles.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: What happens if brakes become too hot?
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick in to cool the brakes
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they may overheat and stop working. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: If using spring brakes when hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes do not work on all axles. If your vehicle's spring brakes activate due to low pressure in an air brake system, your vehicle will need a longer distance to stop than usual, especially if you are carrying a heavy load.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps to provide additional control during hard braking, but does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially:
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out of adjustment if they are hot. Be sure to routinely check the adjustment of your brakes. For a vehicle to be safely controlled, all brakes must be properly functioning and adjusted.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: While operating on a downgrade, you should brake until you reach a speed that is:
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. Air brakes may cease to work effectively if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: The safety valve located on the first tank opens:
questions.answerB: If there is too little pressure.
questions.answerC: If there is too much pressure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the first tank that receives compressed air has a safety valve that releases air if the pressure gets too high. It is usually set to open at 150 psi. If the valve must open, there is a fault in the system that should be repaired by a mechanic.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: A shut-off valve:
questions.answerA: Is located on the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Is located on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: Prevents air from escaping an air brake system.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerB: A tractor attached to two trailers
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: When glad hands are coupled, the seals should be pressed together at an angle of:
questions.explanation: When coupling, be sure to couple the proper glad hands. When glad hands are connected, the seals should be pressed together at a 90-degree angle.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will often continue to move in a straight line.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: When braking while pulling a trailer equipped with anti-lock brakes, you should:
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the brakes kick in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would without anti-lock brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: Before a trip, you can make sure air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Checking for moving air inside of each trailer.
questions.answerB: Listening for air at the rear shut-off valve.
questions.answerC: Feeling for air at the front shut-off valve.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: A combination vehicle has:
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles have two air lines: a service line and an emergency line.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for service lines?
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: When traveling more slowly than 40 mph, maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect can:
questions.explanation: Trailers can overturn as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect. The last trailer in a combination is the most prone to tip over due to this effect. Drivers should be aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles and drive accordingly.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Does not change braking in any way.
questions.answerC: Will allow the driver additional control over their vehicle when braking.
questions.answerD: Will cause extra strain on the other axles.
questions.explanation: Having an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) on only the trailer, or even on just one axle, will still provide a driver with additional control over the trailer when braking.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: Combination vehicles need extra space on the road because they:
questions.answerA: Drive more slowly than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are heavier than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Need more space to turn and stop than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the brake pedal harder than usual.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal as you normally would.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal more lightly than usual.
questions.explanation: When operating a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should apply your brakes in the same manner as you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect can:
questions.explanation: Trailers can overturn as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect. The last trailer in a combination is the most prone to tip over due to this effect. Drivers should be aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles and drive accordingly.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: Operating combination vehicles usually requires ­­­­­____ operating single vehicles.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: Pushing in the trailer air supply control will:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: Maintain a following distance of at least ____ for every 10 feet of your vehicle if you are traveling at a speed under 40 mph.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: When backing up while coupling a trailer, the tractor should be positioned:
questions.answerA: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.
